importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, during early morning hours, marking a significant aviation safety event at Hong Kong International Airport.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident happened at approximately 3:50 a.m. local time, during the early morning arrival phase, which is a critical period for airport operations and crew activity.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea.
The aircraft, a Boeing model, broke in two upon landing and struck an airport security patrol car, killing two occupants.
The four crew members on board were treated for injuries, and there was no cargo on board.
The aircraft did not emit distress signals during approach, indicating a possible failure in handling or landing procedures.
Hong Kong International Airport suspended operations on its north runway for safety assessment and recovery.
Despite the severity, operations on the other two runways continued, minimizing disruptions to over 1,000 daily flights.
The flight was officially operated under Emirates flight number, but the aircraft was wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major carriers.
The incident highlights the rare but serious risks in aviation safety, especially at one of the world’s busiest and most complex airports.
The airport has a history of major accidents, including a 1999 typhoon-related crash, underscoring ongoing safety concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish carrier ACT Airlines, flying under an Emirates flight number, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) early Monday morning, crashing into the sea and killing two occupants of a nearby security patrol car. The Boeing aircraft broke in two during the landing, with no distress signals sent by the pilots. All four crew members on board were injured and treated at local hospitals. The airport suspended operations on the north runway for safety checks, though other runways remained operational, minimizing flight disruptions. The incident, while rare at such a busy airport, underscores ongoing safety challenges and historical precedents, including a 1999 crash at HKIA involving a China Airlines flight during a typhoon.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
